title: Booting an existing installation of Windows 7 from USB

forumNotes.author: ray_juped
forumNotes.content: Unfortunately, my PC's onboard SATA controller has become fried, rendering my computer nearly unusable. (I went through a lot to narrow down the problem to this cause.) I really can't afford to do anything about this, however, I do have a SATA hard drive dock with ESATA and USB connectors. The ESATA works slightly better than the internal SATA, but I still experience plenty of problems. However, since my external USB HDD works just fine, I'd like to boot from the same drive in USB mode instead. When attempting this, I get a BSOD with STOP 7B during boot. I have tried both PWBoot and USBBootWatcher, but I still got the same STOP 7B after installing each one. Since I don't really know what I'm doing here, I'm asking for help getting it to boot.

forumNotes.author: ktp
forumNotes.content:
I think **karyonix** 's tutorial would solve your problem. Take a quick look at:  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=9196](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=9196 "External link")  

Some steps in the tutorial are not necessary in your case.  
Following are the steps as I can see:  

1- boot Windows 7 with your HDD as eSATA.  
2- be sure to have administrator rights. Excute the two batch files in this order :  
- usbbootfix.bat  
- StorageBootStart.bat   
(the above two batch files should be downloaded and stored in a separate directory).  
3- shutdown Windows 7.  
4- reboot Windows 7 with your HDD as USB2.

forumNotes.author: ray_juped
forumNotes.content: Thanks. I still get 7B while booting, but after running both batch files, it now comes later in the boot process. Before, it BSODed at classpnp.sys, now it does so at disk.sys.

forumNotes.author: ktp
forumNotes.content:
@ray_juped  

Could you tell me how do you manage to see the different drivers loading at boot time? Under XP I know there are options in the boot.ini, but with Vista/Window 7 I no longer know how to do this. Thank you.

forumNotes.author: ray_juped
forumNotes.content:
> Could you tell me how do you manage to see the different drivers loading at boot time?

bcdedit /set sos on
